captions.text:
Nobody's born smart
We all start at 0

Can't talk, can't walk, certainly can't do
algebra

Adding, reading, writing, riding a bike --
Nobody's good at anything at first

There was a time when Einstein couldn't count
to 10, and

Shakespeare had to learn his ABC's
just like the rest of us

Thankfully, we're born to learn
Slowly, surely, you stumble, slip, crawl,

fall, and fail, and fall
Frustrating, confusing, trying, struggling

One foot in front of the other
One idea on top the next

Each wrong answer making your brain a little
bit stronger

Failing is just another word for growing
And you keep going

Knowing that you'll get it even if you haven't
gotten it yet.

Because the most beautiful, complex concepts
in the whole universe are built on basic ideas

that anyone can learn, anywhere can understand.
Whoever you are, whereever you are

You only have to know one thing:
You can learn anything

comments.text:
That isn't right. People are born with a set level of abilities and skills. 
These set abilities and skills are the only one you can become any good at 
and there is nothing that can be done about that. for example, anyone can 
learn how to play a guitar, but unless you were born with the ability to 
learn how play a guitar you will NEVER become really good. Everything 
you're very good at you were born with the innate ability to do so because 
if you weren't, then you would be just like everyone else who tries it; a 
failure. ﻿
comments.author: CaramelColored

comments.text:
+Dragons in my Realm It is true that people are born differently, i mean we 
all have different height, weight, eyes.. etc etc, however some natural 
things cannot be changed like your height but you can however work out and 
build your muscles, and research has found that brain is the exact same, 
the more complex things you try the better your brain works. We do however 
start of differently, people can start of different stages than you, your 
education, culture, and the way you think can also play a role in this. So 
yh i agree :)
comments.author: taz pking

comments.text:
+CaramelColored i disagree. it may take more or less practice for certain 
people, but if I really wanted to be a better basketball player, I could 
pick up my basketball and walk over to the middle school and shoot and 
shoot and shoot, and eventually, it may take a while, but eventually I'll 
be getting better and better. Skill development is not an exponential 
thing, where there is one line that is never touched. That line can be 
touched.

comments.author: Nathan Holstrom

comments.text:
+Dragons in my Realm​ it's a very fitting analogy to use in the Nature vs 
Nurture debate. Which in upon itself is not that accurate because Nature & 
Nuture both have inherent points that don't cancel each other out. But the 
point still stands that the best Nuture in the world isn't going to produce 
Tesla, Einstein, Edison, Mozarts... those were men who were just better 
then the rest of us. There's a reason why Carrera Marble is the most sought 
after and expensive stone to do carvings with... as opposed to granite. The 
same basic laws apply to human just like every thing else, some people are 
just inherently better than other people at certain things.
comments.author: Nathan Holstrom

comments.text:
+Nathan Holstrom and on top of that I'm not sure what you meant when you 
said that if a statue was granite it would be bad. Humans are a bit more 
complex than stone, so you can't really compare the two. Also if someone 
really worked at carving granite into a sculpture, are you really saying 
that he / she will NEVER finish? That's a little strange. The only reason 
they wouldn't is if they didn't have any proper tools.
comments.author: Dragons in my Realm

comments.text:

way, if you haven't learned that yet in your somewhat long life
comments.author: Dragons in my Realm

comments.text:
+Nathan Holstrom there is no way to prove that a certain person can not be 
able to do something. And also when you're in a debate try to be a little 
more mature and actually show that you're an adult. Seriously.
comments.author: Dragons in my Realm

comments.text:
+Dragons in my Realm stupid as fuck point!!!!! It wouldn't matter if it was 
Michelangelo himself carving it, if the stone itself was granite as opposed 
to Carrera Marble then the statue would be dogshit. Albeit a higher level 
of dogshit than anyone else is capable of producing but definitely not a 
priceless work of art like David. 

So yes Nurture can definitely improve Nature but Nurture alone is 
insufficient to obfuscate Nature entirely.... we are not all born equally. 
Get the fuck over it... there's a reason why Tesla is remembered when 
millions upon millions never will be. Because such mix of genetics created 
a mind so advanced it ended up being squandered in its time.
comments.author: Nathan Holstrom

comments.text:
+Dragons in my Realm my philosophy is that we might be further away from 
different things in life, but if we all work at it we can achieve it. 
Anybody can be fit and skinny, but first they have to work at it. Some 
people have to work at it less, because they have a high metabolism.
comments.author: Dragons in my Realm

comments.text:
+Nathan Holstrom Einstein and Tesla both worked immensely hard for their 
accomplishments. I think its better to say no average human being would 
have the level of passion that those two scientists had
comments.author: Dragons in my Realm

comments.text:
+Nathan Holstrom The premise of the video is that it's possible to learn 
anything and be good at anything even if you fail a ton. Einstein and 
Shakespeare were just probably used for extra emphasis. No one said you 
will be a genius at everything, but what is a genius? Is a genius just 
someone who focuses on something regardless of failure? regardless of time, 
money, willpower? I'm under the impression that a genius is just someone 
who is able to hyper-focus on a subject until they have reached a level 
beyond mastery from all the time they've put in. Granted, different people 
have different innate abilities (someone who's mentally handicapped is 
going to have a much tougher time learning something than someone who 
isn't). Still it's an interesting thought.
comments.author: Matthew Mullin

comments.text:
+Nathan Holstrom I have to agree, it's not reasonable to say that Einstein 
or Mozart weren't born with a high amount of natural intelligence. An 
average human just isn't capable of those kind of feats. If we were all 
capable of making revolutionary physics discoveries, it wouldn't have taken 
us this long to discover the mass-energy equivalence formula or general 
relativity. That takes devotion and intellectual abilities that very FEW 
possess.

That being said, you have to consider all of the scientific, artistic, and 
musical achievements by people who weren't naturally gifted. These people 
had to push their limits, work hard, and use their brains to discover 
something that the world has not yet seen. With the overwhelming amount of 
scientific research and discoveries being made in ALL corners of the world 
from many different people, it's safe to say that humans are able to push 
themselves to greatness. It doesn't come naturally for most, but it sure as 
hell can be achieved.
comments.author: PurpleScarz

comments.text:
+Sakib Moghal how is that not a logical point...? The video was comparing 
Einstein's or Shakespeare's inability to read to everyone elses... that's a 
facetious point. Of course people could probably be taught to process 
information better than rote memorization of information that's going to be 
on a standardized test... but to say that everyone has the innate ability 
to be Einstein or someone like Tesla (who while recently having become 
popular, I remember that 20 years ago when I was a teenager nobody knew who 
he was) who has all kinds of theories about what he figured out, the real 
truth is we have no idea what he figured out and haven't been able to 
replicate the verified stories of the things he was doing even now. 

I'm just calling bullshit on the premise that we are born equally 
intelligent... we are not. Mozart wrote full symphonies in a single draft. 
Genius and hyper intelligence are something that you are born with... 
education can make people think better but that won't help their raw 
intellect potential.
comments.author: Nathan Holstrom

comments.text:
Well, that was silly. Perhaps you could learn how to create logical 
arguments?

You can learn anything, after all :)
